subject: Autodetect hypervisor presence to set libvirt_type
commit_message:
Autodetect hypervisor presence to set libvirt_type

Users can now set libvirt_type to auto (which is now the default)
which will use the built-in libvirt auto-detection to detect
a hypervisor at run time.  This value is then retrieved from
libvirt and cached for future use, and is accessible via
hypervisor_type (which will use libvirt_type if it is explicitly
set).  In case a libvirt connection is not readily available
and a hypervisor type is not passed to us (as in the case of
some of the util functions in the virt/libvirt directory),
a connection is made for the purposes of determining the hypervisor type,
and is subsequently closed.  All applicable calls to CONF.libvirt_type
have been replaced with driver.hypervisor_type (or the like,
as explained above).

Implements: hypervisor autodetection
Fixes: bug #1100366
Change-Id: I57d60c02afdd30557ddd3dd773886de8cbd2efbc

subject: Do not raise NEW exceptions

except SomeException:

store information about exception then do all actions and then

subject: Introducing PATCH support for Swift.
commit_message:
Introducing PATCH support for Swift.

An attempt to allow Swift to host efficient cloud-sync services.
Currently, an attempt to implement such services will result in a waste of bandwidth when objects are changed.
This happens because on each change, the entire object has to be re-uploaded.
Therefore, implementing a "PATCH" method for objects, allows us to send only the change and not the entire file, saving precious bandwidth.

In addition, we can throw in a FUSE based client as a proof of concept.
Combining the two, one can "mount" a Swift container onto the filesystem and any user-land application can work with those objects as if they were normal files.

The range in the object to be patched is supplied via a Range header. Currently, only one range is supported.
If the request is successful, the data that was in the given range will be replaced by the data in the request.
If the end of the range is bigger than the size of the object, the object's size will increase.

Example request:
PATCH /v1/<account>/<container>/<object> HTTP/1.1
Host: storage.swiftdrive.com
X-Auth-token: XXXX
Range: bytes=0-10
Content-Type: application/octet-stream
Content-Length: 10
[...data to patch...]

Responses can be "Bad Request" if no range or more than one range is supplied.
On success, "No Content" is returned.

Changes are made to:
[-]object controller: redirect requests to the nodes
[-]object server: patch an object based on the "range" header and the content.
[-]container server: updates the container's metadata based on the changes made to the object.

Implements:  bp/object-patch-support

subject: Stop getting useless bytes on manifest Range requests.
commit_message:
Stop getting useless bytes on manifest Range requests.

If you make a range request for a manifest object, then the proxy can
retrieve more data than it actually needs from the object server. It
sends the right bytes to the client, and then spends a bunch of time
reading and discarding bytes it doesn't need.

Example:

   file start  	       	       	       	       	       file end
       |	range start	  range end		  |
       v	     v         	       v       	       	  v
       [--------------------------------------------------]

The proxy would send a request to the object server with "Range:
bytes=${range start}-", and so the object server responds with all the
bytes from range start to file end. This needlessly transfers all the
bytes from range end to file end, as none of those are sent to the
client.

This commit fixes the sent Range header to only request the bytes
needed.

Change-Id: Ie8d4ee2c5e67c08795ac2d39d1df7d11856621a9

subject: Harmonize account and container GET/HEAD statues as per RFC 2616.
commit_message:
Harmonize account and container GET/HEAD statues as per RFC 2616.

From RFC 2616, section 9.4 ("HEAD"):

    The HEAD method is identical to GET except that the server MUST
    NOT return a message-body in the response. The metainformation
    contained in the HTTP headers in response to a HEAD request SHOULD
    be identical to the information sent in response to a GET request.

This change makes account and container GET and HEAD responses have
the same status codes in all cases. This doesn't make the headers
always match because that would be too expensive (in terms of SQL
operations), but that's okay since header equality is only a
recommendation ("SHOULD").

The changes are all to the HEAD responses; GET is unchanged.

Examples of mismatching requests:

$VERB /v1/account[/container]   (when nonempty)
$VERB /v1/account[/container]?format=json
$VERB /v1/account[/container]?format=xml
$VERB /v1/account[/container]?delimiter=/
$VERB /v1/account[/container]?limit=two%20beers
$VERB /v1/account/container   (when empty)

Examples of matching requests:

$VERB /v1/account   (when empty)
$VERB /v1/account[/container]   (when drive not mounted)
$VERB /v1/account[/container]   (when deleted)
$VERB /v1/account[/container]?format=mp3

Bonus fix: the Content-Type for GET /v1/a/c was "text/html" for an
empty container and "text/plain" for a nonempty one; now it's always
"text/plain".

Change-Id: I5ab1eb85e777f259f4bd73a3a4a1802901925ed7

subject: Allow reboot or rebuild from vm_state=Error
commit_message:
Allow reboot or rebuild from vm_state=Error

In general most operations are only valid on an
instance that has booted successfully at least once
so this change extends the instance state check
logic to include evidence that the instance has
been successfully started at least once.

This enables more operations to be allowed in
against instances in an Error state.  For example
reboot and rebuild are useful recover options for
an instance which has reached an error state, but
not if the instance failed during its initial build.

With this change the only actions allowed on an
instance which has never booted successfully are
delete and force_delete.  Soft delete is not
allowed, as the restore is in effect a start unless
there is specific virt driver support.

In addition the following actions are now allowed
against instances in an Error state providing the
instance has booted at least once:  Reboot, Rebuild,
and Rescue.

The concept of a reserved namespace for instance metadata
is intended to support the Heat autoscaling use-case.

When spinning up new instances in a autoscaling group, Heat
will set some additional user metadata on the instances to
identify their group membership.

Previously, instance user metadata was not captured in the
metering store and thus could not be queried on.

Now the reserved namespace(s) are used to signal to the
compute agent that some user metadata should not be discarded.
This allows the statistics for a group of associated instances
to be aggregated in a single query.

Swift functional tests sends ilegal headers (unicode) and expects
these headers to be processed by Swift.

Apache2 seem to remove such headers which is a sound behavior for
illegal headers.

This change restrict the test tpo exist only for swift integral
web front end. For future it is advised to disallow such behaviour.
For example it is suggested to make the decission that in future APIs
illegal headers are removed rather than processed.
